# Packages

These are some of our favourite packages, with most appearing many times throughout the book. We thought it would be nice to feature them more conveniently here.

::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
<a href="https://galah.ala.org.au">
![](images/hex/galah_logo.png){.hex-logo} </a>
:::


::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### galah

[galah](https://galah.ala.org.au) is an R and Python interface to biodiversity data hosted by the
Atlas of Living Australia (ALA). It enables users to locate and download
species occurrence records (observations, specimens, eDNA records,
etc.), taxonomic information, or associated media such as images or
sounds, and to restrict their queries to particular taxa or
locations.
:::
:::


::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}

<a href="https://here.r-lib.org/index.html">

![](images/hex/herepkg.png){.hex-logo} </a>
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### here

[here](https://here.r-lib.org/index.html) is a package for easy file referencing in project-oriented workflows. The here package creates relative paths relative the top-file directory in ways that are more robust from errors. Artwork by [allison_horst](https://x.com/allison_horst?lang=en).
:::
:::


::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
<a href="https://docs.ropensci.org/skimr/">
![](images/hex/skimr_logo.png){.hex-logo} </a>
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### skimr

[skimr](https://docs.ropensci.org/skimr/) is a package for providing rich summaries with summary statistics of data in R. Users can `skim()` these summary statistics to quickly and more completely understand their data.
:::
:::

::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
<a href="https://www.tidyverse.org">
![](images/hex/tidyverse_logo.png){.hex-logo} </a>
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### tidyverse

[tidyverse](https://www.tidyverse.org) is an opinionated collection of R packages designed for data science. All packages share an underlying design philosophy, grammar, and data structure. Some notable
packages within the tidyverse are dplyr, tidyr and ggplot2.
:::
:::

::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}

<a href="https://github.com/mdsumner/ozmaps">

![](images/hex/ozmaps_plot.png){.hex-logo} </a>
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### ozmaps

[ozmaps](https://github.com/mdsumner/ozmaps) is a package that hosts a collection of Australian mapping spatial object data: coastlines, state outlines, local government areas and electoral boundaries. It streamlines the process of downloading shapefiles of Australia. Data for ozmaps is derived from the Australian Bureau of Statistics (2016). 

:::
:::

::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
<a href="https://r-spatial.github.io/sf/">
![](images/hex/sf_hex.png){.hex-logo} </a>
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### sf

[sf](https://r-spatial.github.io/sf/) allows users to encode spatial vector data. The sf package provides access to [simple features](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simple_Features) in R, allowing users to conduct geometrical operations using coordinate reference systems for spatial data manipulation.

:::
:::

## General cleaning


::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
<a href="https://dplyr.tidyverse.org/"> 
![](images/hex/dplyr_hex.png){.hex-logo} </a>
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}

### dplyr

[dplyr](https://dplyr.tidyverse.org) is a popular package for data manipulation, providing a consistent set of verbs (e.g., `filter()`, `select()`, `mutate()`, `group_by()`) to restructure your data. 

:::
:::


::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
<a href="https://tidyr.tidyverse.org/"> 
![](images/hex/tidyr_hex.png){.hex-logo} </a>
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### tidyr

[tidyr](https://tidyr.tidyverse.org) is a package to help you make "tidy data", where each variable is a column, each observation is a row, and each value value is a cell. 

:::
:::

::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
<a href="https://stringr.tidyverse.org/">
![](images/hex/stringr_hex.png){.hex-logo} </a>
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}

### stringr

[stringr](https://stringr.tidyverse.org/) is a package with a cohesive set of functions to filter, match and correct strings and characters. 

:::
:::


::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}

<a href="https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/janitor/vignettes/janitor.html">

![](images/hex/janitor_logo.png){.hex-logo style="padding-left:34px!important; padding-right:20px!important;"} </a>
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### janitor

[janitor](https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/janitor/vignettes/janitor.html) is a package with a collection of helper functions for initial data exploration, summarising and data cleaning.
:::
:::


::: {style="display: flex;"}

::: {style="width: 25%;"}
<a href="https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/">

![](images/hex/ggplot2_hex.png){.hex-logo} </a>
:::

::: {style="width: 75%;"}
### ggplot2

[ggplot2](https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/) is a package for visualising data using [The Grammar of Graphics](https://r4ds.had.co.nz/data-visualisation.html), where users assign variables to display, the type of graphics to use, and additional aesthetics or theme formatting. 
:::
:::


## Taxonomic validation

### taxize

[taxize](https://docs.ropensci.org/taxize/articles/taxize.html) allows users the ability to search taxonomic names over many taxonomic data sources using scientific and common names to resolve synonyms in their data.
